Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Juan Ramon

texts.es:
El señor Juan Ramón C. es un caballero que siempre se ha destacado por trabajar mucho y llevar el sustento a su hogar siendo uno de sus principales características el velar por su vivienda. Hoy en día trabaja en el área de jardinería siendo esta actividad la que le permite obtener los ingresos para su desarrollo. 

Actualmente la vivienda del señor C. se encuentra en mal estado por lo que muy preocupadamente ha solicitado un crédito para hacer reparaciones al techo y al piso y de esta manera continuar beneficiando a su familia. Espera en que su crédito le sea otorgado satisfactoriamente y así lograr la satisfacción de su familia.
texts.en:
Juan Ramón C. is a gentleman who has always stood out for his hard work, and providing for his household is one of the main characteristics he values. Today, he works in gardening since this activity allows him to earn income for his development. Currently his home is in poor condition. Very concerned, he has requested a loan in order to make repairs on the roof and floor and in this way his family can continue to benefit from his work. He hopes that his loan is approved and thus please his family.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Manuel Antonio

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, el señor Manuel G. se ha destacado por ser muy trabajador y preocuparse por las condiciones de su familia compuesta por su esposa y sus tres niños.

El señor Manuel trabaja como guarda de seguridad y vigilancia y a pesar que este trabajo es muy cansado, él siempre busca la manera de sobre esforzarse y llevar el sustento al hogar. El crédito que ha solicitado es para la compra de materiales de construcción porque requiere mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda como lo son el techo y el piso y para ello necesita invertir directamente en la compra de dichos materiales para brindarle a su familia muy buenas condiciones de vida y garantizar que sus hijos tengan un techo digno y herencia donde habitar.
texts.en:
In the city of Managua, Manuel G. has stood out for his hard work and his concern for the well-being of his family, consisting of his wife and three children. Manuel works as a security guard and although this job is very tiring, he's always looking to work hard and provide for his household. The loan he has requested is to purchase construction materials he needs to improved the conditions of his home, like the roof and the floor, and to do that he needs to directly invest those materials. This will help him provide his family with good living conditions and guarantees that his children have a proper roof to live under and inherit.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Mario José

texts.es:
Actualmente el señor Mario Velásquez atraviesa la necesidad de mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda por medio del cambio del techo de su casa y por ello solicitó el crédito para invertirlo en la compra de los materiales de construcción y así brindarle excelentes condiciones de vida a su familia.

El señor Mario Velásquez espera ser beneficiado con el crédito para así adquirir a lo inmediato los materiales de construcción y de esta manera iniciar con la reconstrucción del techo para cubrirse tanto él y su familia tanto del frio, la lluvia y otros fenómenos climaticos.
texts.en:
Mario Velásquez currently is in need of improving his living conditions by putting a new roof on his home, and for this he is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of construction materials. In this way he can provide his family with excellent living conditions. Mario hopes to benefit from this loan by immediately purchasing those materials to start rebuilding his roof to protect his family from the cold, rain and other weather events.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Dania Antonieta

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, la señora Dania O. se dedica a laborar arduamente con el único propósito de llevar el sustento a su casa de habitación compuesta por sus dos pequeños hijos. Ella es madre soltera y por esta razón tiene la responsabilidad de mantener a sus pequeños y brindarle los estudios para su desarrollo intelectual.

Ella actualmente solicita un crédito para buscar la manera de cómo abastecer las necesidades de su hogar y cancelar algunas deudas para continuar llevando el sustento a sus pequeños hijos y brindarle las condiciones para su desarrollo.
texts.en:
In the city of Managua, Dania O. dedicates herself to working hard with her only goal being to provide for her household, consisting of her two small children. Dania is a single mother, so she has the responsibility of caring for the kids and providing for their intellectual development. She is requesting the loan as a way of supplying her home with necessities and to pay off some debts so she can continue providing for her young ones and have living conditions that contribute to their development.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Provide for family's well-being

loans.name: Francisco Salvador

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, el señor Francisco R. se dedica a laborar para lograr mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda la que ha estado dañada a raíz de los fenómenos climatológicos presentados en su localidad.

Como padre responsable, vela por el bienestar de sus hijos y para ello busca la manera de como brindarles las condiciones necesarias de vida. Es por esta razón que solicita el crédito para comprar los materiales de construcción para iniciar esta obra hasta terminarla y luego sentirse satisfecho por haber reconstruido su vivienda.
texts.en:
In the city of Managua, Mr. Francisco R. works in order to improve the condition of his home, which has been damaged as a result of harsh weather in the region.

As a responsible parent, he is concerned about his children’s well-being, which is why he is looking for a way to provide them with the necessities of life. For this reason, he is requesting a loan to purchase construction materials to get the work on his house done. He hopes to feel satisfied after having rebuilt his dwelling.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Claudea

texts.en:
Mrs. Claudea S. is a 46-year-old woman who is currently living at Lumbayao, Aloran, with her lived-in partner. She is an old member of PMPC and she is already on her 7th regular loan.

Claudea is requesting a Php 5,000 loan to be used as additional capital for her sari-sari (variety) store. Her husband’s income is not enough for their daily living so she needs to operate her business well to increase their income. She wishes to see her family succeed in their chosen field of business.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Ou H., 27, is married and has two children. She lives in the province of Kompong Tom, Cambodia, where she earns a living as a requirement worker, while her husband (pictured) is a furniture seller. She is also hired by neighbors to plow or harvest their rice crops. Her husband also goes to buy beds in bulk from people who live in the rural area and then takes them to sell by retail from door-to-door. Ou H. finds that her husband’s business selling beds is a profitable one, so she would like to improve it by using the loan she is requesting.

loans.use: To improve a selling bed business.

loans.name: Lory

texts.en: Lory N. is from the town of Aloran. She is 57 years old, is married, and has six adult children. Lory owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Lory joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use this amount as startup capital for her new business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as startup capital for her new business

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
Mrs. Bonifacia E., 61 years of age, is a resident of Mandih, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She has four children.

Bonifacia is a member of PDP-LP or Paglaum Development Program for Landless People. She has obtained a loan of Php 3,000 which is intended for her banana and charcoal vending business. Her customers are the people in their village and people of neighboring places.

Bonifacia started this business with only a small amount of capital. Her future plan is to make this business big in order to cater to her customers from faraway places.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her banana and charcoal business

loans.name: Norng

texts.en: Norng R., 49 years old, owns a small shop in her village where she sells food to people at lunchtime. She typically makes around $2 of profit each day to meet what her family needs. She is married and has a child. Her husband is a local cultivator (he appears in the picture). Norng R. has been planning to build a new house for a long time but she doesn't have enough money to begin the construction. She is taking out this loan to afford the construction of a small house for her family.

loans.use: To build a new house.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: Mrs.Merlita S., 44 years old, was married and raised three children on her own. A resident of Mohon, Aloran Misamis Occidental, she operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising corn to sell in the future. Merlita joined Paglaum MPC because of the programs and services and she is now applying for a loan amounting to Php 5,000 as additional capital to purchase fertilizer for corn production. Her future plan for her son is to see him finish his college studies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Apolinario

texts.en:
Apolinario R. is from the village of Libertad Bajo, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. He is 65 years old. Apolinario is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Apolinario owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Apolinario has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Apolinario joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Apolinario is requesting a loan of 2,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Apolinario from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his agricultural business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Edita

texts.en:
Edita C. is from the village of Sto Nino, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Edita is separated from her spouse and has 2 school-aged children. Edita owns & operates a business venture raising pigs for sale. Edita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Edita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Edita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Edita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea S. is a rattan cupboard seller who is 36 and is a married father caring for two kids who are pupils in the local public school. Since 2006, Chea S. and his wife have owned a small rattan cupboard sales point. This couple also orders rattan items in bulk from braiders and then takes it to retail door-to-door across the province. They always take a week or two weeks in selling their products.

Chea S. is now running his business very well because he sells his items at a reasonable price. In order to better satisfy the needs of the customers, Chea S. seeks a US$ 800 loan to stock a bigger amount of rattan cupboards to sell.

Note: Chea S. was not available at the time, so his wife is shown instead.

loans.use: To have a bigger amount of rattan cupboards to sell

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan G. , 52 years old, resides at Siayan, Zamboanga del Norte. Married, he is blessed with 5 children. His wife is a businesswoman but the income of his wife is not enough for the needs of their family since their children are all in school. The school miscellaneous expenses and tuition fees have increased, so he has found a way on his own to support his wife. He owns a small sari-sari store and sells gasoline and oil lubricant which he started with a small amount of capital.

He has been an active member of Paglaum since September 2009. He is thankful that Paglaum has come to their place because he believes that it can help to put more capital into his business, while he enjoys the programs and services of Paglaum. He has applied a loan to PMPC in the amount of Php15,000 as additional capital for his business.

loans.use: additional capital for his business

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry C. is from the village of Sto Nino, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Cherry is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Cherry owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Cherry has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cherry joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cherry is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Cherry from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: April Joy

texts.en:
At the age of 23, April Joy is engaged in buying secondhand motorcycles and selling them again in her village, though most of her customers are from different places. Her father is her business partner. Every time they sell a motorcycle, she has a net income of Php 5,000.

April Joy plans to obtain a loan of Php 8,000 as additional working capital for her business. She hopes that Kiva will grant her loan immediately. According to her it will be a great help in meeting the needs of their customers.

April Joy is married to Roel R., who works as a call center agent at Metro Manila, Philippines. They have one daughter named Mariah Kristen Kaye, two years old. They live in the village of Calaocan, Cabatuan, with her parents-in-law. Their house is located near Iglesia Ni Cristo church.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her motorcycle-trading business

loans.name: Sam-Ol

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam-ol S., 30 and her husband, Mr. Sam-ol Kroch, 38, have been married since 1994 and have one young son. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sam-ol has been a silk weaver since she was 13 years old, a skill she learned from her aunt. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then takes them to sell in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a security guard for 19 years.

Sam-ol is asking for a loan of $100 to purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business

loans.name: Chenda

texts.en:
Mrs. Chenda U., 30 and her husband, Mr. Vichet Sdoeng, 33, have been married since 1998 and have two young sons. They live on an island in the Mekong River aboU. fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chenda has been a silk weaver since 1996, a skill she learned from her aunt. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village where she lives, who then takes it to sell in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a barber.

Chenda is asking for a loan of $250 to buy silk materials (raw silk) for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
The two people shown in the picture are Mrs. Nov P. and her husband.

Nov P., 22, is a requirement worker who is also hired by village to keep the farm. Her husband is a furniture maker. This young couple has been married a year and has been blessed with a small child. Nov P. finds it hard to commute anywhere, because she has no vehicle. Therefore, she decided to seek a loan to purchase an old motorcycle for touring.

loans.use: To purchase an old motorcycle for touring

loans.name: Pheary

texts.en:
Mrs. Pheary M., 39, is widow with three sons. One of her sons is a driver for a company and other two are attending school. She lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh about 25 kilometers away.

Pheary has been selling rice in a local market for 3 years. She now is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to buy a motorcycle for her son to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to work.

loans.name: Tan

texts.en: Tan S. is a 31-year-old farmer who resides in the best territory of Kompong Tom, in a good location for farming. To earn a living, Tan S. plants potatoes and peanut trees on her own piece of farmland. She currently earns approximately of $2 a day to contribute her family. To provide more income for family, her husband is a blacksmith for a small firm. The family lives with two school-aged children. Tan S. will be using her first loan to purchase a motorbike, which she and her family will use for traveling purposes.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Viseth

texts.en:
Mr.Viseth E., 40 and his wife, Mrs. Muyteang Eang, 38, married in 1990. They have 4 children: 1 son and 3 daughters. One of thE. has full-time employment in Phnom Penh City, two are in school, and other one is still young. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty Kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Viseth has been a goldsmith since he was married. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. Viseth doesn’t have enough material for operating the business, so he is requesting his first loan of US$ 300 to purchase materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for his goldsmith business

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta has been involved in a hog-raising business for almost seven years. She says she already sold two hogs thus only one hog is left. She is requesting a loan of Php 8,000 as her capital in purchasing piglets to raise and a supply of hog feed for their food. She wants to access her requested loan to pursue her business again. She uses her income for the needs of their family. She hopes that her business will again be supported by generous KIVA lenders for the welfare of her family.

Marietta is 39 years old and married to Rizaldy, a classifier of rice and corn grain. They are blessed with two children namely; Raymart, 17 years old, a first year college student, and Jennifer, 12, a first year high school student. The family resides near the barangay (township) hall in the village of Calaocan, Cabatuan.

loans.use: hog feed and a pig to raise

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Khat L. K. is a 50-year-old widowed mother and a farmer. Khat L. K. proposes to use her loan to repair her broken cultivating machine that she uses to alleviate her hard labor in the farm business. She has three children; two are married and live away from home, and one is single. To help support the family, two of the children are employed: a son is farmer and a daughter sells a few cakes in the village.

Khat L. K. and her daughter are pictured.

loans.use: To repair her broken cultivator

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Oeun T., 51, and her husband, Mr. Sam-at Chhum, 57, have been married since 1978 and have 5 children. Three of them are married and live in separate homes. The couple is living along National Road 10 about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Oeun has been selling grocery items for 1 year. She also grows rice for food as well. Her husband has been a security guard for 5 months. She is requesting her first loan of US$ 250 to use for growing rice.

loans.use: To use for growing rice.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Mrs. Sina C., 33, has been operating a business renting out space in her house to garment factory workers since 2006. Because her house is located near a garment factory, it’s good for her to pursue this business. She has two sons and one daughter. All of them are in school. Her husband, Mr. Sakun Chhun, has been a driver since 1986. The couple lives in a small village along National Road Number Four about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sina is applying for her first loan of US$ 500 in order to purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.name: Soeu

texts.en: Soeu L., 41 years old, is a married mother caring for three kids who are students in the local public school. For years, Soeu L. and her husband have owned a handicraft business, which they run, from their home. They produce rattan baskets for sale. They also sell their products in bulk to middlemen who then take them to retail at the market. The demand for their craft is so high, almost all of their customers need to wait a few weeks before they can meet the orders. This couple can make about $5 of income per day. Besides the current work, the family has also always cultivated a rice crop. Soeu L. is applying for a loan to buy a cow in order to aid her farming business.

loans.use: To buy a cow in order to aid her farming business.

loans.name: Enkhtaivan

texts.en:
Enkhtaivan L. is 27 years old and lives with her husband and 2-year-old-son in Uvurkhangai province, central Mongolia. Her husband, Ankhbayar, supports the family by driving a taxi in the local area. L. operates a clothing and mink hat retail business. She travels to China twice a month to import clothes, which she transports back, to sell at the local market in her town. In the wintertime, she travels to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to purchase mink hats. These hats are expensive to purchase, but they are in great demand during the cold Mongolian winters. 

L. started her business after graduating from college. Finding quick success in selling clothes, she used her savings to purchase and expand her business to include selling hats. The hats have proven to be quite profitable and she continues to increase her sales and her earnings. L. is a very open-minded business woman, and credits her success to her good communication skills and positive relationships with her customers. For the future, she hopes to expand her business and open her own trading center. She is requesting a 2,700,000 tugrug (~1900 USD) loan to import more clothes from China and to purchase mink hats to sell this winter.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To import more clothes from China and to purchase mink hats to sell this winter.

loans.name: Adiya

texts.en:
Adiya T. is 61 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt housing tent. His oldest son is a buddhist lama, his only daughter is a university student, and his youngest son attends a local secondary school. T. operates a clothes trading business in his town. He sells a variety of clothing items out of a shipping container located near the local goods market. 

T. started his clothing business in 1997 with the working capital of 100,000 tugrugs (~70 USD). At first, he rented a small stand at the market where he conducted his business. He has been able to use his earnings to buy the shipping container. Today, his business operates at a stable level and he has a good reputation amongst both his customers and the supplier. His working capital now exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD). For the future, T. hopes to continue to expand his business and to increase his earnings. He says, "My wish is to educate my children and to expand my business." He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to purchase clothes to sell.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mr. Pov C., 59, and his wife, Mrs. Eng Rous, 55, were married in 1972. The couple lives on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.  

Pov has been selling cows since 1982. He buys them from other districts far away from his home to resell in his village. He has asked for a loan one time already. He is now requesting his second loan of $700 to continue expanding his cow-selling business.

loans.use: To continue expanding his  cow-selling business.

loans.name: Gombosuren

texts.en:
Gombosuren G. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His oldest daughter, Naranzul, attends a local secondary school. The younger children, a son and daughter (ages, 1 and 3), stay at home with their mother. His wife works as a hairdresser, when she isn't looking after the little ones. G. has operated a taxi service in his town since 2008. He uses his own car to transport people around his local area. 

In his first year of operation he has found modest success as a driver. He works very hard, always looking for ways to improve his service and to increase his earnings. Since he started driving, he has increased his working capital from 80,000 tugrugs (~56 USD) to 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). For the future, G. hopes to save enough money in order to open a small salon for his wife. He says, "My future business goals are to buy a car for myself and a place for my wife to operate her business." He is requesting a 400,000 tugrug (~280 USD) loan to purchase parts for his car.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase parts for his car.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
S. is a 27-year-old married mother who currently lives in Kompong Tom province in Cambodia. She is married with two school-aged kids.

S. is a Khmer cake seller from her home, selling the cake that she produces there. Another source of family income comes from her husband's sales of rattan (thin, pliable stems of palm, used to make furniture).

Because selling rattan is a profitable business for the family, S. requested a loan to provide additional capital for her husband’s rattan-selling business.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her husband's rattan-selling business

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo P. is from the village of Sto Nino, Talakag Bukidnon. He is 56 years old. Eduardo is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Eduardo owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to transport passengers within the community. Eduardo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Eduardo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eduardo is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Eduardo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Lorn S., 57, is a widow with 9 children (she is pictured with her daughter). She lives along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Seven of her children are married and live outside the family home.

Lorn and has been a farmer for 30 years; she grows rice and vegetables. She now is requesting her first loan of US$ 500 to pay for plowing and purchase fertilizer and pesticide to put on her rice and vegetable farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and pay for plowing

loans.name: Shar

texts.en:
Shar O. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Uvs province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son and daughter, ages 14 and 11, attend a local secondary school and her youngest son is 1 year old. O. operates a traditional shoe-making business and a grocery business in her town. She produces traditional Buriad and Mongol shoes which she sells at the local market. Her husband is retired and helps her to operate the grocery business.

O. started her shoe-making business in 1990 and has built up a good reputation in her area over the years. She used her savings from making shoes to later start the grocery business. Today, both businesses are operating successfully and provide her family with financial stability. O. hopes to continue to grow her businesses in the future and improve her family's quality of life. She says, "One can achieve success with hard work." She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to purchase materials used in shoe-making.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase materials used in shoe-making

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie M. is a 30-year-old woman living in the town of Faleasiu Tualesolo. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Marie operates a family member's business, a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marie has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 500 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Marie joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marie is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Marie plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Miss Socheat H., 24, is single (she is not in the photo, but her mother was available instead). She has 7 siblings and lives with her mother in a small village along National Road Number 5 about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Socheat has been a garment factory worker for 6 years. Her mother is a rice farmer. Socheat is requesting her first loan of US$ 600 to pay school fees for her brother who is learning motorcycle repair skills and help as capital for her mother in her farming business.

loans.use: To pay school fee for brother and as capital for her mother

loans.name: Hoàng Thị's Group
loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

Petina E. is a 66-year-old woman living in the town of Faleasiu Tualesolo. She is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Petina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Petina has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 350 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Petina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Petina is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Petina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca L. is from the village of Sto Nino, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Rebecca is widowed and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Rebecca owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rebecca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rebecca is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rebecca from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Luse

texts.en:
Luse M. is a 30-year-old woman living in the town of Faleasiu Tualesolo. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Luse owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Luse has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 500 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Luse joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luse is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Luse plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Sherill Jane

texts.en:
Sherill Jane A. is a bona fide resident of Barangay Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She was born on March 02, 1982 and finished secondary education. Due to financial difficulties she did not pursue her college education. She looked for a job and helped her parents to earn a living.

After two years, Sherill Jane married Darwin A. and they are blessed with two children. Being parents, they want their children to have a bright future by giving them the best education they can. Despite the economic crisis, they are doing all their best to earn a living for their survival and to finance the schooling of their children.

As a way of gaining income, Sherill’s husband works in construction while Sherill is engaged in selling frozen foods in their village. She borrowed additional capital from one of the microfinance organizations which she used to acquire the frozen foods at Solano public market. She sells them through house to house delivery.

Being an industrious mother, Sherill is able to earn a net income of Php 700 a week which she adds to her husband’s income to acquire their basic needs and to finance the schooling of their children.

Due to the high cost of commodities and school expenditures, they need to earn more to meet their daily needs. Thus, Sherill is again requesting a loan amounting to Php 8,000 to be used in acquiring more frozen foods for her to sell in their village. She believes that she can improve her small business through this financial assistance, given her patience and sacrifices.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Chy

texts.en:
As everyone knows, fish is the main vital fresh food for everybody, in particular families who depend on fishing and fish-selling, from Tunle Sap River, where the best place is for fish sheltering. Mrs. Chy R., one among those people, currently depends on selling fish at the local busy market. She sells fish that she either gets from her husband’s fishing or buys from her wholesale supplier.

Chy R. is a humble mother who has been blessed with four school-aged children. Chy R. has requested a loan to purchase more equipment to supply her husband's fish-catching business.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment to supply her husband's fish-catching business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
According to Elizabeth, being friendly and having a good moral character is necessary in managing a business. Elizabeth is 58 years old and married to Carlito who is a driver. They have four children namely: Lilibeth-29 years old and a college graduate; Andrey-23 years old who graduated from Hotel and Restaurant Management; Kristel-21 years old, a Midwifery graduate; and Rhizel-20 years old who just finished a two-year course.

Elizabeth is managing a sari-sari store in the village of Rizal, Santiago City. She would like to buy additional merchandise but her capital is not enough that’s why she would like to ask KIVA lenders for a loan amounting to Php 5,000, allowing her to purchase more merchandise to sell.

loans.use: additional capital for her general store's  improvement

loans.name: Jenevie

texts.en:
Jenevie T. is from the village of Calube. She is 25 years old. Jenevie is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Jenevie owns and operates a "sari-sari" store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jenevie has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jenevie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenevie has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Jenevie is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Jenevie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
The smiling-faced person shown in the picture is Mrs. T., who lives with her family members in Siem Reap Province. T., 55, sells various kinds of vegetables at the market and earns approximately US$ 2 profit a day. Besides her current work, she also cultivates rice on her own farmland.

T. was married, but her husband died of senility, and she has seven children. T. runs her business very well because she has skills in communication which she uses with her customers. To meet the needs of her customers, T. is looking for a loan to buy various vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To buy various vegetables to sell

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita is 37 years old and married to Jacob, Sr. who runs their vulcanizing shop. Her family lives in the village of Calao East, Santiago City. The couple is blessed with six children, namely: Jacela-16 years old and a college undergraduate; Melanie-14 years old, a high school student; Rose Anne-7 years of age, an elementary pupil; Jacob Jr.-6 years old, an elementary pupil; Jasmine-1 year old and Jacqueline-9 months old.

Angelita manages a store and the vulcanizing shop which is situated where her neighbors frequently pass by. She would like to develop their vulcanizing shop and buy more merchandise for her mini-store to further improve their stanard of living and to be able to pay for the schooling of her children. In this regard, she would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from KIVA lenders for additional merchandise and the improvement of their vulcanizing shop.

Angelita dreams of having a productive business for the future needs of her children. She would be glad and thankful if her request loan is granted.

loans.use: additional merchandise for her general store and  improvement of their vulcanizing shop business

loans.name: Asoono

texts.en:
Asoono P. is a 39-year-old woman living in the town of Faleasiu Tualesolo. She is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Asoono owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food products in the local community. Asoono has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 350 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Asoono joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Asoono is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Asoono plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Si

texts.en:
There are many Cambodians who make a living as rice cultivators. One of them is Mrs. Si M., who has been working in this sector since 1979. She grows her crop on her own farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. From this business she can generate an income of around US$ 3 per day.

Si M. was married, but divorced her husband when her three kids were very young. One of her sons works in a hotel. This coming crop season, Si M. hopes to plant an sugar cane crop and is asking for a loan to buy seeds to begin growing, as well as to buy a water pump for irrigating her crop.

loans.use: To buy seeds and a water pump for irrigating her crop

loans.name: Filiga

texts.en:
Filiga T. is a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Alamutu E. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Filiga owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ice cream in the local community. Filiga has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 300 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Filiga joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Filiga is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Filiga plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Lê Thị's Group

texts.en:
"H. Lê Thị (10107070060) is a 43 year-old woman living in the town of Đông Anh - Hà nội. H. is the group leader of a 3-member group L. offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual L., they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Xuân Trạch 07 (5).

H. is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, H. operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising ducks for sale. H. has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2006, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. H. has successfully repaid a previous L. of 5.300.000 VND from SEDA. This previous L. was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. She is now requesting a new L. of 6.322.000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 5th L. taken out by the borrower from SEDA. H. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. Đào Thị L. (10107070014) is a 45-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.014.000 VND L. to support her fishing business.

2. Nguyễn Thị T. (10107070011) is a 53-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.014.000 VND L. to support her manufacturing business.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this L. was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

H. Lê Thị (10107070060) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà nội. H. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Xuân Trạch 07 (5).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi vịt để bán. H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 3.500.000 VND. Vào 2006, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.300.000 VND từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.322.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. Đào Thị L. (10107070014) là 45 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.014.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.

2. Nguyễn Thị T. (10107070011) là 53 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.014.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất.

Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva."

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Pey

texts.en:
Pey S., 29, lives Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She earns a living by selling grocery inventory, such as cooked food and sweets for kids, from her house. She has been in this business for a long time.

Pey S. is married and currently takes care of two children, all of whom are single and also attend school, whilst her husband works in construction.

Pey S. works hard every day and is a very responsible to her family. Recently, she sold all her groceries from her store. Because selling groceries is Pey S.'s main way to earn an income to support her family, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase a range of grocery item to sell. She proposes to use the rest of the loan to buy a piglet to raise.

loans.use: To purchase a range of grocery item to sell

loans.name: Naneth

texts.en:
Naneth B. is from the village of Sto Nino, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 19 years old. Naneth is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Naneth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Naneth has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Naneth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Naneth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Naneth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Chum S. is 30 years of age and currently lives in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. Chum S. is a local professor who teaches classes for pupils, while her husband is a civil service officer who works in the Ministry of Interior. This couple has two young children. Chum S. finds it hard commuting to work because she has no vehicle for her traveling needs. Therefore, she asks for a loan to add to her saving to buy a used motor for riding to her workplace.

loans.use: To buy a used motor for riding to work

loans.name: Yoem

texts.en:
L. is 24 years of age and a single woman. She lives in a small stone house in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. L. currently lives with three siblings, two brothers and one sister, who work in different jobs.

To earn a living, L. is working as an internal staffer for a night club and gets a specific salary of $120 a month. To earn additional income, L. would like a loan of US$500 to use as capital to begin selling snack food from a location in front of her work place. L. and her brother are shown in the picture above.

loans.use: To begin selling snack food

loans.name: Zar Ghona

texts.en:
Zar Ghona is daughter of Q. D.. She is married with three children. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. Her two sons and one daughter are students at school. She is 45 years old.

Zar Ghona wants to take an individual loan for her business of tailoring. She wants to buy necessary materials for her business and wants to make her new shop larger and buy new machines for her business. She expands and progresses her business and she has more clients in the business.

Zar Ghona thanks AFSG and all Kiva lenders for the small loans process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: expand and grow her business

loans.name: Eyde_Qorban Group

texts.en:
Salaha is the group leader of 'Eyde_Qorban' group. There are two members in this group. Salaha is a married woman. She is 34 years old and she has two daughters who are school students and Salaha wants to take a loan for her bakery. She wants to make her shop larger and expand it.

Sayweta wants to take a loan for her tailoring business, and she wants to expand and progress her business. She makes a shop in her house; she is a married woman and she has one daughter who is small. They have requested a group loan of 20,000 Afghani.

They would like to thank both AFS and Kiva lenders that support the people around the world through their effective process.

loans.use: make their businesses larger

loans.name: Pom

texts.en:
Mrs. Pom S., age 34, lives in her own small house with other family members in Kompong Tom province. To earn a living, she sells retail cooking ingredients that she buys in bulk from the market at reasonable price. Some of her clients are her nearby neighbors, who also buy her produce on credit for a few days.

To help be responsible for family, her husband works in construction for a profit. This couple has two small kids. Pom S. requests a loan to purchase a motorcycle, which she will use for touring purposes.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle, which she will use for touring purposes

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Pilar A. is a 42-year-old mother of 10 school-aged kids, married, and a resident of Makawa, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She and her husband are both expert at making 'nipa' (palm) roofs and this activity is their major source of income. Despite having many children, Pilar and her husband are really working hard in order for them to support their family.

Pilar decided to join PMPC to gain access to financial services and now, she is already on her second loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional 'nipa' leaves because the orders from their customers are now increasing. The profit will be used to be sure their children finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy 'nipa' leaves to be used in making palm frond roofs

loans.name: Saaf Group

texts.en:
This is Saaf group. This group is made up of three members. Khalilullah is the group leader. He is 25 years old. He is married, having two children, one son and one daughter. He sells mobile cards and through that income he supports his family and also pays the bills of the household. These three members have requested a group loan of 30000 Afghani.

Najibullah is 22 years old, married, and the second member of Saaf group. He has a business selling fuel. Waqifullah is the third member of Saaf group; he has a retail food shop. They all want to grow their businesses. Khalilullah is insuring that they repay the loan on time, and they want to continue their partnership with both Kiva and AFS (Ariana Financial Services Joint Stock Company) in the future. And they all thank Kiva lenders around the world.

loans.use: to grow their individual businesses

loans.name: Marichel

texts.en:
Mrs. Marichel P. is a 28-year-old, married and living at Punta Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She has two school-aged children. Her husband is a fisherman, and this is their primary source of income. Her husband's catch is sold at the public market or to their neighbors. Their fishing business sustains their daily needs despite weather conditions.

Marichel joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to help them with financial assistance. This is her first loan amounting to 5,000 PHP which will be used to acquire more fish to be sold because the catch of her husband is not enough. In the future, she hopes to own a stall in the public market to display their fish.

loans.use: buying fish to be sold in the neighborhood

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma T. is from the village of Dela Paz. She is 48 years old. Alma is married and has adult children. To make a living, Alma owns and operates a snack vending business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Alma is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Alma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly M. is 48 years old and married to Beneto M., who is 51 years old and works as a driver. In the long years of their marriage, they were given five children: Raymund, 21 years old; Benito, 18 years old; Kimberly, 16 years old; Nelson, 14 years old; and Maih Cecilio, 9 years old. One of their frustrations as parents is that most of their children have been able to attain only a low level of education because of they have insufficient income to pay for their educational expenses, especially since they have more children that they need to send to school. Their dream is their other children be able to finish their studies because education is one of the things they needed to fight against poverty.

Nelly and her husband work hard for this. They have two sources of income: she is running a variety store business, and her husband works as a driver. She has been running her variety store business for 10 years now and she really wants it to grow more.

Since she became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she has used every loan that she received to improve this business. She is a very good member of ASHI. She has been in the institution for 9 years; she started in the year 2000. Now, her 12th loan will be used again for this business: she will buy what her store needs, like sacks of rice, different groceries and many more items that will sell in her store. She is hoping that after buying all of these, her business will be more productive and continue growing.

Aside from dreaming that their children would finish their studies someday, she also dreams of turning their variety store into a mini grocery store so that they will earn more for their family. That is why they will work hard--for the fulfillment of these dreams.

loans.use: To finance her variety store business

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina A. is a hog raiser in the village of Sto. Tomas, Saguday, Quirino.  She and her husband Orlando, who is a farmer, are blessed with two children: nine-year-old Ribelyn and four-year-old Jessica. The couple are working hard to improve their lifestyle, and they hope to provide for the needs of their family through Rosalina’s business.

Rosalina would like to obtain a loan in the amount of PHP 4,000 for the renovation of her pig pens and the purchase of feed for her hog-raising business. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her request.

loans.use: additional capital for the development of her hog-raising business

loans.name: Valeriana

texts.en:
Valeriana L. is from the village of Maular. She is 51 years old. Valeriana is married and has 8 adult children. To make a living, Valeriana owns and operates a "sari-sari" store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Valeriana is just starting this business.

In 2005, Valeriana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Valeriana has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Valeriana is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Valeriana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Teofila

texts.en:
Teofila A. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 46 years old, married, and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Teofila owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling beverages like soft drinks in the local community. Teofila has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Teofila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teofila is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Teofila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta D. is from the village of Pangabuan, Tangub City. She is 42 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Julieta owns & operates  an "Olang" fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Julieta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to purchase raw materials for her business. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP for the purchase of additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children’s schooling and the family’s daily needs.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes is 59 years old, and has four children with her husband Roman, who is a farmer. Three of her children are already married. They live in the village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela.

Mercedes is in the hog-raising business. In a desire to improve her business, she is now applying for a PHP15,000 loan from KIVA lenders. She will use the capital to purchase feed and additional piglets, which she will raise to increase her income.  She is hoping that her request will be granted by KIVA lenders so she can provide for her family and make her business profitable.

loans.use: to purchase feed and additional piglets

loans.name: Akhpalwak Group

texts.en:
This is the 'Akhpalwak' group. There are four members in this group. The leader of this group is Azada. She is a married woman. She lives with three children in Khair Khan, Kabul, Afghanistan. She has two sons and one daughter. They are at the university and Azada’s husband is a teacher. Azada wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. She needs three new disks for her tailoring.

M. Kabeir and Sayad Nasa want to take a loan for their business of selling carpets. They produce and import carpets from Harat and sell them in Kabul. They want to develop and improve their business.

Akhpalwak also wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling car parts. He wants to buy necessary materials for his business. And he wants to expand and develop his business.

With this loan they can make their businesses larger and support their families and make a better future for themselves and also for their families in the future.

loans.use: Improve and expand their businesses

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is 27 years old.  She and her husband Victorino, a company driver, are blessed with three healthy children who are currently enrolled in elementary school. They reside in the rural village of Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela.  

Analiza is determined to develop her skills in managing her poultry business, which provides her with a good living. She raises chickens and sells them after 30 days for PHP 115 per kilo.  Through these sales, she generates an income of PHP 4,000 a month, which is a big help in meeting the daily needs of her family and maintaining the productivity of her business. She is requesting a loan from KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP 11,000, which she needs to purchase chicken feed and additional chicks to raise. She hopes that her business will further improve with the help of this loan.

loans.use: to purchase chicken feed and more chicks to raise

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan S. is from the village of Talakag , Bukidnon. She is 53 years old, married, and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Susan owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling hogs to butcher for a meat vending business in the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Susan is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Susan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is 48 years old and a resident of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. She is married to Florante, who works as jeepney driver in their village. They have three children, two of whom are still studying. 

Elvira has owned and operated a canteen in her village for more than ten years. She sells different commodities such as snacks, drinks and junk food. She earns a net income of PHP 300 a day from her business, and she is glad that she can provide for the daily needs of her family.  

Elvira is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 from KIVA lenders to maintain and further expand her business. With the loan, she can purchase additional items to sell, such as breads and other commodities that will appeal to her customers.  She hopes that her loan will be granted because it will surely help her business to grow, and through her business, she hopes to fund her children’s education all the way through college.

loans.use: to purchase more items for her canteen

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma O. is from Gango Ozamiz City. She is 37 years old, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Elma owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling "bagoong"-based food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing salted food and selling cooked food for daily meals. Elma has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Elma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Sharifa Razya Group

texts.en:
Sharifa is the group leader of Sharifa Razya group. Their are four members in this group. Each would like to receives money for her/his business.  Sharifa is married with six children: four daughters and two sons who are in school.  One boy also works in a video shop. Sharifa wants to take out a loan for another son who works as a mechanic and wants to start his own shop. 

Halema wants to take out a loan to purchase two machines for her embroidery business.  Razya wants to take out a loan for her husband’s general store so that he can buy the necessary materials for his business.  Shaysta wants to take out a loan to expand her tailoring business.

Their requested group loan is for 40,000 Afghani. Thanks to all lenders of Kiva and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: materials for their businesses

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana A. is 36 years old. She and her husband Ariel, 37, reside in the village of Santiago, Reina Mercedes, Isabela, along with their two children, Kenny Jay and Karen. Kenny Jay is a junior high school student while Karen is a Grade 1 pupil. As a mother, Susana really wants to give her children a better future by financing their education; thus she and her husband are working hand in hand.

Wanting to make her hog-raising business more progressive, Susana is asking KIVA lenders for a  PHP 5,000 loan, which will help her to buy feed for her animals. Her business serves as her main source of income, and she very much wants to make it more productive so that she can meet her family’s basic needs, as well as the educational needs of her children.

loans.use: to buy feed for her animals

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Conception

texts.en:
Conception E. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 56 years old, married, and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Conception owns & operates a specialized retail store.
