The main source of income for the business comes from selling bananas in the local community. Conception has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Conception joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Conception is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Conception from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Luke

texts.en:
Luke G. is 25 years old; her husband is a doctor. She has one child who goes to school. Luke is currently in the business of selling charcoal and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to purchase more goods like maize flour, charcoal for stoves, etc. to sell. With the profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a retail shop.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, targeted towards war refugees returning to their native home, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more goods like maize flour,charcoal for stoves, etc. to sell

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette E. is from the village of Talakag in Northern Mindanao’s Bukidnon province. She is forty years old, married and has four school-aged children. Bernadette owns her own business selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, to the local community. She has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Bernadette joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first with HSPFI, of 5000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional seafood products to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional seafood products to sell

loans.name: Ledy Jane

texts.en:
Ledy Jane and Jesus S. reside in Nueva Vizcaya province on the island of Luzon. Their home is in Barangay Uddiawan, located in the municipality of Solano. They are blessed with two grown children, Joemark and Jermilyn. Being responsible parents, they did their best to support the studies of their children until they graduated from college. At present, the eldest is working abroad while their second child is teaching at San Juan Elementary School. They believe that their lives are the fruit of their patience and sacrifices. 

Since they are now growing old, the couple continuously works to further improve their living conditions and save for their future. Jesus cultivates their farm plots, planting rice and corn, while Ledy Jane manages their small eatery at home. Being a responsible worker, she is able to earn a net income of 4,500 PHP a month, which she uses for their daily needs and puts into savings for their future. Ledy Jane aims to improve her small eatery, but she has inadequate capital to do so. 

Through Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. (ASKI), Ledy Jane wants to borrow PHP6,000 from KIVA lenders to be used to acquire needed materials and ingredients for her eatery as well as the maintenance of their crops. She is thankful for this financial assistance, as it gives her the opportunity to improve Jesus' and her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy food and materials to support her small eatery and crops

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden J. is currently in the business of selling goods like sugar, bags of salt, soap, etc. and is requesting a loan to purchase goods such as: maize flour and milk to sell. Kiden is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by opening a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase goods such as: maize flour and milk to sell

loans.name: Yean

texts.en:
Yean N., 31 years old, lives with other family members in Kompong Tom province in Cambodia. His wife named Chenglim, 31, is in the picture. The couple has a small daughter who is a clever student, learning in the local primary school. To earn a living, the family retails beds that they produce or buy from carpenters. They own a trailer-motorbike which they use to pick up beds to sell door-to-door around the community, and they usually generate an income of US$ 10 per day to buy food for their family.

Recently, Yean N. has ordered many sets of beds on credit from his carpenter but he doesn’t have enough money to pay his supplier. Because of that, he decided to request a loan of US$ 500 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL.

loans.use: To buy many beds to sell

loans.name: Mohammad Sabar Pajsheiry Group

texts.en:
Ghullam Mastafa is the group leader of M. Sabar Pajsheiry group. There are four members in this group. The group leader is Ghullam Mastafa, he is a married man and lives in district of 15th Kabu,l Afghanistan.  He wants to take out a loan for his business of selling fuel because he wants to expand his business. 

M. Sabar wants to take out a loan in order to purchase a new taxi and in order to help his family. Ahmad Henf wants to take out a loan for his general store as he wants to expand and progress his business. Pashton Gull wants to take out a loan for her quilt making business. She wants to buy necessary materials for her business.

They have requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani. 

They would all like to expand their businesses and support their families through the loan.

loans.use: expand and progress their businesses

loans.name: Norng

texts.en: Norng S. is 64 years of age, a widow woman, and currently lives in a medium-size wooden house in Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia. She has two children and she was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. Norng S. and her children own a small handicraft business; they turn rattan into furniture for sale. Norng S. will be using her Kiva loan to purchase more rattan for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more rattan for her furniture making business

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is engaged in fruits and vegetables vending, selling items such as bananas, string beans and ginger. Aside from selling fruits and vegetables, she is also engaged in the hog-raising business. For two consecutive years, she has worked hard to have a source of income just to support the needs of her children. She usually sells her commodities every afternoon. 

Leonora is requesting a loan of PHP8,000 from Kiva lenders for the development of her business. She will use the loan to purchase more vegetables to sell. She hopes that her loan will be granted because it will assist her in making her business productive.  

Leonora is married to Bayani, an operator of heavy equipment in a construction site in Surigao. They are blessed with two children: Nyeeshien, nine years old, in grade three, and Benyan Leo, five years old, already in pre-school. She and her husband are helping one another in providing the needs of their family, especially in meeting the needs of their children.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more vegetables.

loans.name: Phourng

texts.en:
Phourng V., 41 years old, is a married woman and the mother of three children. They currently live together in a medium-size old wooden house located in Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia. Phourng V. is hired by her neighbors to harvest their crop, while her husband is a motorbike taxi rider.

Phourng V. is taking out her loan to repair her husband’s taxi, which is not attractive to the customers.

loans.use: To repair a motor taxi.

loans.name: Paryman Gull Group

texts.en:
This is Paryman Gull group. There are three members in this group. The group leader is parman Gull. She is married, has two daughters and lives in Kabul, Afghanistan.  She wants to take out a loan for her bakery as she needs stock for her business and would like to make her own shop. 

Nazera wants to take out a loan for her tailoring business as she needs three new machines in order to improve her business. Zar mena wants to take out a loan for her brother’s fruit business. He wants buy necessary materials for his business.

They have requested a group loan of 28,000 Afghani.
     
They are confident that with the money they receive can make a good profit and can run their businesses in a good way. They all are happy about the process of applying for a loan and want to say that it can support the entrepreneurs a lot.

loans.use: to expand their business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 32 years old, married to Julius Gaitungu and they have three school-going children. She has been recycling metal and iron sheets to make products like grills, iron sheets for roofs, and water pipes for sale in Naivasha town for the last 10 years. Mary was introduced to KADET by her friend who is also a client. This will be her first loan and she plans to use the funding to buy raw materials to make the products which she sells. Her dream is to buy her own piece of land where she can make and sell her goods from. About KADET The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more metal (raw materials) for her business.

loans.name: Florfina

texts.en:
Florfina is an industrious mother and a loving wife to Tomas. One of her guiding principles is "patience is the key to success and productivity." She manages a hog-raising business. Whenever she sells a hog, her net income is Php5,000.

Florfina wants a loan of Php10,000 from KIVA lenders to purchase some hog feed and some hogs to raise. She is grateful because there are people who are generous to give financial assistance to the needy.

Florfina and Tomas are blessed with four children namely: Robert, 31 years of age, forestry graduate and now working abroad; Rona, 29, public school teacher; Rocky, 25, also working abroad; and Rose Ann, 22, working as a radio technologist. Florfina and her husband peacefully reside in the village of Calamagui San Pablo Isabela Cagayan. Florfina said that she's happy with what she has right now, because she feels a lot of contentment in her life.

loans.use: Additional capital for her hog-raising business

loans.name: Huon's Group

texts.en:
There are three low-income people who have decided to request a loan, which they will use for various purposes.

Mrs. Huon T., 41 years of age, has been selected to be the leader of the loan group. She currently lives with her five children and her husband. To earn a living, Huon T. has owned a small farming business since 1990. She plants different kinds of crops and she harvests her matured crop three months after she begins growing. Huon T. has requested a loan to buy a palm step for her husband, which he will use to climb the palm trees.

The other borrowers are Mrs. C., a rice grower, who is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer for her crop, and Mr. T., a local farmer who is requesting a loan to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy a palm step for her husband to climb the palm trees

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon, 38, is married to Susan Wanjiru and they have four school-aged children.  He has been selling food products (potatoes and cereals like maize) in Naivasha town for the last two years.  

He learned about KADET through a KADET promotion that was held around his business area. This will be his first loan with the organization, and he plans to use the loan to add cereals to the food products he sells.

His immediate plan for the future is to save to buy a piece of land on which he can run his business.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add cereals to sell at his shop

loans.name: Dudu

texts.en:
Dudu C. is sells food at a resturant in the market premises and is requesting a loan to purchase soda and water to sell in the restaurant. Dudu is 22 years old and is widowed. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase soda and water to sell in the restaurant

loans.name: Norvelyn

texts.en:
Norvelyn A., 44, is married to Leo A., who is a tricycle operator. They live in the village of Calao East, Santiago City. The couple are blessed with two children: Julius, a 19-year-old college undergraduate, and Jay Vee, a 14-year-old who is presently enrolled in high school. Norvelyn and her husband really value education, but due to financial constraint their eldest child was forced to stop his studies. They do wish that he will be able to continue his schooling someday.

Norvelyn is a vegetable vendor in the village. She sells sprouted mongo and has her own plot of sprouted mongo at her house. She would like to improve her business by asking for additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to 4,000 PHP. This would mean a lot to her, especially to help meet her family's needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for business development

loans.name: On's Group

texts.en: This is a small loan request for two borrowers. The leader, Mrs. On I., age 36, has been a garment worker since 2002. On I. lives with her three teenage children, one of whom works sewing clothes, while the other two attend school. To help meet the family's needs, her husband drives a motorbike taxi. On I. requests a loan to invest in a fishing business. The other borrower, Mrs. Bun M., is a fresh fish seller who is requesting a loan to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To invest in a fishing business

loans.name: Feisal

texts.en:
Feisal, 34, is married to Ann Mukumbu and they have a 2-year-old child.  He has run his butcher shop in Naivasha town for the last three years. 

He was introduced to KADET by his friend who is also a client. This will be his first loan with the organization, and he plans to use the loan to add more goat and chicken meat to sell to customers.

In the future, Feisal plans to open a restaurant to run alongside his butcher shop. He hopes the extra profits he will earn as a result of this loan will contribute to this goal.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase meat

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter, 38, is married to Mary Njoki and they have three school-age children.  He has been selling clothes in Niavasha town for the last three years.

He heard about KADET through one of KADET's promotional events around his business area.  This will be his second loan and he plans to use it to add to his inventory of clothing to sell to customers.  He paid the first loan well and on schedule.

In the future, Peter hopes to expand his business by moving into a bigger clothing shop. 

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Chhay

texts.en: Chhay S. was born in 1957; she is married and blessed with four children. Her husband, Kim Heap, is 55 years old and works as a taxi driver. To make a living, Chhay S. has built a small store in front of her house, where she sells a few groceries for a profit. Chhay S. will be using her loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie manages a carinderia (local eatery) in the village of Calao East, Santiago City. She is married to Reynaldo and they are blessed with three children who are all college graduates. She is thankful because all of her children finished their studies.

Lanie would like to ask for a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 PHP, which will allow her to develop the carinderia she manages. Lanie dreams to expand her carinderia to encourage more customers to go to her place. She would be glad if her request is approved. This would serve as a big help to her, most especially in her business development.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Kari

texts.en:
Kari P. sells used clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more pairs of trousers, bedsheets and other items to sell. Kari is 40 years old and is married to a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase trousers, bedsheets and items to sell

loans.name: Akot

texts.en:
Akot L.  is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials. Akot is 40 years old and is married to a soldier. She has seven children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a big bar.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more brewing materials

loans.name: Roselily

texts.en:
Roselily is 40 years old and is married to Domingo, a tricycle driver. They have five children: Reychelle Ann, 18 years old and a second year college student studying management; Joana Marie, 16 years old and a college student; Ria Abigail Michael, 24 years old and a college graduate; Mark, 21 years old and a high school graduate; Mariel, 12 years old and in the first year high school; and their youngest is Marvin, 8 years old, who is a grade II student. They live in the rural village of Calamagui San Pablo, Isabela Cagayan. 

Roselily is engaged in beauty services. She offers manicures, pedicures and hair cutting, and she earns a daily income of 200 PHP. Their other source of income is though a motorcycle transport business operated by her husband. She wants to obtain a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 15,000 PHP for additional requirements in her business, and for the education of their children. She hopes and prays that Kiva lenders will grant her a loan in order for her to have a productive business.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van L. is 50 years old and has been selling fresh fish in the local busy market for more than four years. Van L. has been blessed with two children who are married and live away from home, while her husband is a domestic ox trader. Van L. owns a plot of land that she inherited from her mother and she hopes to grow crops on it. Van L. asks for a loan to buy fertilizer and watermeL. seeds to plant.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina I. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables, beans, and fish, and is requesting a loan to stock cowpeas and maize flour to sell.  Lina is 41 years old and is married to a primary school teacher. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a big retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock cowpeas and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
With her desire to expand her store, Elvira T. decided to request a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 10,000 PHP for her to purchase commodities to sell in her store. She knows that through this loan, her income will increase because she can meet the demands of her customers, thus she is really hoping that lenders will approve her loan.

Elvira is 48 years old and married. She and her husband live in the village of Calamagui San Pablo Cagayan, where farming is the major source of income among the residents. The couple are blessed with three children who are studying in a local school in Tuguegarao City. Her husband, Rafael,  is 47years old and works as a farmer and driver. Whenever he is not busy at their farm, he is driving a passenger motorcycle to earn extra income. Elvira also manages a hog raising business. She shared that usually their children help them in cleaning the pig pens, especially during weekends.

loans.use: To purchase items for resale

loans.name: Abue

texts.en:
Abue M. is currently in the business of purchasing and selling bread and is requesting a loan to buy more goods, such as sugar, milk powder, etc., for resale. Abue is 35 years old and is married to a policeman. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and build a new house.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy goods for resale

loans.name: Nuth

texts.en: The photo is of Mrs. Nuth C. with her husband. Nuth C. is a homemaker who cooks delicious meals for family and is also a good mother, caring for five children. The family is supported by her husband, who works in the ministry of art. Four of the children are employed in different jobs and they provide their income to help cover the family’s needs. Nuth C.’s husband always needs to spend money to take a taxi to work. To help reduce expenses, Nuth C. is applying for a loan to purchase a used motorbike for her husband to ride to work.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorbike for her husband to ride to work

loans.name: Chab

texts.en:
Mrs. Chab L. lives in Chuos village in Takeo province. She is a 24 years old and is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this, she also sells rice soup in the village. Her husband, Mr. Maong Phearum, helps her in the business.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than needed to support their family living. Thus, Mrs. Chab L. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten more piglets to raise. This couple does not have any children. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

loans.use: To buy ten more piglets to raise

loans.name: Phou

texts.en:
Mrs. Phou T. is a widow with three children, one of whom is a garment factory worker while the other two study at the local school. She lives in Pris Leu village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Phou T. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She is also a pig breeder.

Since this business is going well, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fifteen piglets for breeding.

She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living condition with this loan.

loans.use: To buy fifteen piglets for her pig breeding business.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: At the age of 35, Susana R. is still single. She lives in Barangay Calamagui, San Pablo, Isabela, with her niece. Having a generous heart, she is supporting the educational needs of her two nieces, who are presently enrolled in secondary and tertiary level of education. Her main source of income is through her retail store. Aside from her store, she also owns a small farm lot. She hired someone who will cultivate and plant palay (rice plant) and vegetables at the farm. But due to the high cost of commodities, Susana wants to request a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 20,000 PHP for her to acquire more commodities for her store. If the loan is granted, she will purchase stocks of soft drinks and canned goods. Aside from that, she will utilize some of the loan to buy fertilizer for her farm. She is optimistic that her loan will be granted.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en:
Mr. Yeng N. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Sin Art, is a garment factory worker. Mr. Yeng N. has two children: one is working and the other is attending the local school. They live in Pris Leu village in Takeo province. 
Although they work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mr. Yeng N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. He hopes to improve their living conditions after he sells the cow. 
His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Chey

texts.en: Chey Y. was born in 1979 and is married with four single children who are employed as garment workers. Her husband works in construction to help cover the family’s expenses. Chey Y. sells Khmer cake and buys recycling for resale to raise income. She has also cultivated rice during the coming farming season for years. From those investments, she can make around $5 each day. Chey Y. is applying for a loan to sustain/improve her recycling sales business.

loans.use: To improve the business

loans.name: Gagu

texts.en:
Gagu C. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase other items like cassava and potatoes to sell. Gagu is 60 years old and is married to a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a new house for the children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase food items for resale

loans.name: Rin

texts.en: Mrs. Rin S. lives in Trapeang Pring village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Heng Mao, is a construction worker. Since his workplace is far from home and he usually spends a lot of money on transportation, Mrs. Rin S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to go to work. This couple does not have any children. Her husband is present in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to go to work

loans.name: Aun

texts.en: Mrs. Aun N. lives in Damnak Rovieng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who has a 0.5 hectare field to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Duong Chhum, is a construction worker. Since his workplace is far from house, Mrs. Aun N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work in order to reduce expenses. Mrs. Aun N. has three children who are all attending the local school. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work

loans.name: Hanina

texts.en: Hanina M. is 36 years old and is married to Pablo Jay, who is also 36 years old. They are blessed with two children named Princes Jay, who is 11 years old and a freshman high school student and Mohammad Al-Niesser, who is 10 years old and a grade IV student. They are happily living in the village of Calamagui, San Pablo, Isabela. Hanina has operated a sari-sari store business (community based store) in their village for three years. She wishes for her business to grow for it is a great help in meeting the needs of their family. With her income, she is able to assist her husband who is now working abroad. With her desire to earn more income, she decided to request a loan of 10,000 PHP from lenders for her to buy stocks of commodities. With this loan, she can provide for the demands of her customers.

loans.use: To buy stocks of commodities to sell

loans.name: Kop

texts.en: Kop S., 58 years old, is a villager living in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. To earn a living, Kop S. rents a medium-size kiosk at the market, where she sells beef for a profit. She sells beef that she gets from her husband’s slaughtering. Her husband buys and raises cows for slaughter. Kop S. is blessed with two children, who are married and have already started new family homes. Kop S. is pursuing a loan for capital to buy more cows for slaughtering. Note: Kop S. was not available for photographing, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy more cows for slaughtering

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 24 years old, married to Isaac Kibe, and they have two children (one school going and the other only a year old).  Eunice has been running her retail shop for the last three years in Niavasha town.

She was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a client. This will be her first loan with KADET, and she plans to buy more dry foods in bulk, including maize flour, wheat flour, sugar and rice to sell in her business.  This will add to the variety of goods in her shop, leading to more income, as her clients will not need to go to buy these items somewhere else.

Her hope for the future is to enter the transportation industry which she views as very profitable.  She plans to start off with a motorbike and buy a mini-bus later.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more goods for retail sale: maize flour, wheat flour, sugar and rice

loans.name: Thai

texts.en:
Mrs. Thai V. lives in Prey Kdei village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this, she is a pig breeder. Since this business is doing well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy ten more piglets and feed. Her husband, Mr. Saem Bol, is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to support the family. Mrs. Thai V. is the mother of a 1-year-old child. 
Her husband is present in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy ten more piglets and feed

loans.name: Elgin

texts.en:
Mrs. Elgin C. is 36 years old, married, and presently residing at Punta, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She has two school-aged children. Her husband is a fisherman and this is their primary source of income. Her husband's catch is sold in the public market or to their neighbors. Their fishing activity sustains their daily needs despite the weather conditions.

In 2009, Elgin decided to join PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve their daily living. She obtained a loan from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative. Today, she is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase some items needed to repairing their fishing net.

In the future, Elgin hopes to own a stall in the public market where she can sell their fish.

loans.use: To purchase nylon, rope and other kind of cord to repair their fishing net

loans.name: Clement

texts.en:
Clement C. is currently in the business of purchasing and selling bread and is requesting a loan to buy more goods, such as sugar, maize flour and millet flour to sell.  Clement is 35 years old and is divorced.   She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a new house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
47-year-old Corazon D. R. lives in a remote municipality of Antique province. Along with her five children, whose ages range from nine to twenty-two, and her loving husband, Corazon faces the difficult challenge of their living every day in poverty.

As a mother and a wife she has no higher dream than that her family will be able to live simply. This means that they can eat as regularly as three times a day, and that they can be sheltered in a house that is not dilapidated.

Through developing her food-selling and variety store businesses, that will be financed by the loan she is requesting through ASHI, she believes that no matter how poor they are right now, someday they will be out of poverty because of the proceeds from her businesses. She wants to be able to send most of her children, if not all, through college graduation.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food preparation business, and to buy goods for her variety store.

loans.name: Surn

texts.en:
Mrs. Surn H. is a farmer who owns a 3.5 hectare field to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Keom Phon, is a laborer who makes a small income. Mrs. Surn H. has five children: three of them are farmers and the others are attending the local school. They live in Tuol Kandal in Takeo province.

In her farming, Mrs. Surn H. faces a small problem, because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers to support the field to make it more productive. Thus, Mrs. Surn H. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Mame Dieng

texts.fr: Mame Dieng N. est une femme de 40 ans elle est divorcée et vit avec son unique enfant dont elle a l'entière charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de "MONTAGNE NORD2" depuis un an et demi. Avec son crédit elle renforce sa boutique en achetant divers produits tels que du lait en poudre, des bonbons, des produits de beauté, du sucre etc. les bénéfices réalisés à partir de son activité lui permettent de prendre en charge son enfant et de subvenir à ses propres besoins.
texts.en:
Mame Dieng N. is a 40-year-old woman who is divorced and living with her only child, whom she supports entirely by herself.  She has been a member of Banc Villageois de "MONTAGNE NORD2" for 1½ years.  With her loan, she's bolstering her shop by buying various goods, such as powdered milk, candy, beauty products, sugar, etc.  The profits earned from her business enable her to care for her child and to meet her own needs. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bostering her small-scale commerce

loans.name: Bura

texts.en:
Bura A. is in the business of selling building materials, such as cement, nails, iron sheeting, and so on, in her shop. She is requesting a loan to buy stock timbers to sell.  Bura is 32 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has four children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her shop and pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy stock timbers to sell

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Vorn B., 34, is a married man and a father of two young children. He helps feed his children by working as a construction worker. His wife, Phally, is 26 years old, and she sells a few fresh fish around the community. Currently, Vorn B. and his family also face difficulty with their living situation because their house is too old, and also a part of their house has broken. Therefore, Vorn B. seeks a fund to be used to repair and decorate his existing house.

loans.use: To repair and decorate his existing house

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mrs. Mon S. lives in Tuol Kandal Village, Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Unfortunately, the rice field is infertile; consequently, she decided to ask for a loan, with which she will purchase fertilizer to support the field and to buy pesticides to kill the insects. Her husband, Mr. Bich Tith, is a fisherman and also helps her farm. Mrs. Mon S. is the mother of two children, one of whom is a pig breeder and the other of whom is studying at the local school.

loans.use: purchasing fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Fatou Diop's Group

texts.fr: Fatou Diop N. est une femme de 65 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 12 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de "MONTAGNE NORD" depuis un an et demi. Son crédit lui permet à chaque cycle d'acheter au moins un bœuf, de l'emboucher et de le revendre. Cette activité lui procure des bénéfices avec lesquels elle soutien son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
Fatou Diop N. is a 65-year-old woman who is married and the mother of 12 children.  She has been a member of Banc Villageois de "MONTAGNE NORD" for 1½ years.  For each cycle, her loan is allowing her to buy at least one steer to fatten and to resell.  This business brings in profits with which she supports her husband to support the family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To advance her business fattening cattle

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
65-year-old Erma B. is still fighting against poverty and time as she works to change her family's standard of living. Being the sole provider for her two children, whose ages are 24 and 26, she sees no reason to give up the fight, although she was disappointed with her children’s educational attainment.

She sometimes thinks of herself as not being responsible enough in attending to the financial needs of her children so that they could be able to graduate from college and have a better career for themselves. Still, Erma wants to make use of her remaining capacity and time in running a business and making it sustainable for her children to take over when she is gone.

Through loans she has requested since her membership in ASHI until the present, Erma tries to achieve her goal for the business little by little. Patiently, with ASHI and Kiva to support her, she is determined to wait for her dream to come true.

loans.use: To purchase common commodities to sell in her retail store.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna S. is a villager in Tuol Kandal Village, Kandal Province. She does not have enough money to buy fertilizers to support her field; consequently, she has decided to ask for a loan. She will use most of the money to buy fertilizer; the remainder will be used to find a way of irrigating her crops. Her husband, Mr. Meim Lun, is a fisherman and helps his wife. Mrs. Vanna S. has six children, one of whom works in a garment factory. Two others are farmers; two others are attending the local school. Finally, the youngest one, a five year old, stays home because he is too young to work or study.

loans.use: purchasing fertilizer

loans.name: Florita

texts.en: Florita is from the town of Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Florita owns and operates a fish pond from which she sells fish and crabs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Florita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Now, Florita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and used as working capital for her fish pond business

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
51-year-old Adelina C. sells fish paste and charcoal briquettes.  She runs a sideline business of repairing shoes and umbrellas.  With these simple ways of living, she supports her ten children, sending them to school and providing their daily meals.

She needs additional capital to help build up her business. She requested a loan of 18.000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use that amount to buy supplies for her businesses.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and fish paste

loans.name: Sao Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Sao Ly T. is from Tuol Kandal Village, Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a 2 hectare field on which she cultivates rice. Unfortunately, her field is infertile and has a lot of insects that harm her crops. In order to deal these problems, she's decided to ask for a loan in order to be able to buy fertilizer and pesticides. Any leftover money will be used to hire laborers to plow the field. Her husband, Mr. Chin Theourn, helps her farm. Mrs. Sao Ly T. is the mother of two children, both of whom are attending the local school.

loans.use: purchasing fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: But

texts.en: But S. is 39 years old and a resident of the best territory in Phnom Penh, the capital. She currently works sewing clothes for a garment factory and gets a set salary of $120 per month. She is a single woman and currently lives with her niece in the family home. However, S. is not comfortable because her house often needs to be repaired. She would like a loan to repair her old house.

loans.use: To repair her old house

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 34-year-old single mother of two teenage children, a girl and a boy. For the past three years, she has run a kiosk selling food like chapati and ndengu (like peas but more nutritious). Previously, she supported her family by washing clothes for others at a fee. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase cooking items in wholesale for the kiosk, such as flour and cooking oil.

She describes herself as honest and hardworking and says that since she joined Faulu she has gained more knowledge on business management and improved her savings skills. In the future, she hopes to stabilize her business and move to permanent premises.

loans.use: To purchase cooking items

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida M. is 50 years old and has two children.  She supports her family with her small school canteen and her duckery.  She now has 300 ducks at home.  She wishes to have more capital to be used for the growth of her business.

She’s now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. of 16,000 PHP.  She will use the loan to sustain her business and provide the tuition fees for her children.

loans.use: Groceries and Ducks

loans.name: Federick

texts.en:
Federick A. is currently in the business of purchasing and selling sugar and is requesting a loan to expand her business and buy more items like salt, rice, and so on to sell.  Federick is 40 years old and married to a husband who is a storekeeper. She has eight children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children up to university level.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business and buy more products to sell

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Mrs. Sina C. is from Tuol Kandal Village, Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Unfortunately, she does not have enough money to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the field to make the crop more productive. Consequently, Mrs. Sina C. has decided to ask for a loan. Her husband, Mr. Huy Chhuon, is a construction worker whose small income also supports the family. Mrs. Sina C. has two children, both of whom stay at home because they are four months and three years old respectively.

loans.use: purchasing rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth E. is from the village of Magsaysay, Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 57 years old, is married, and is blessed with two adult children. Elizabeth owns and operates a business selling a variety of food products in the local community, earning Php 2,000 monthly net income from her business. In 2009, she joined PMPC to access its programs and services. Currently, she's obtaining her first loan of Php 3,000 which will be used as additional capital for her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her snack-vending business

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
60-year-old Clara S. is a tricycle operator in Norala, South Cotabato.  She started her business in 2004.  She is a widow and has six children. One of her children bought the motorcycle and sidecar.  The income Clara receives provides the daily needs of her family.

She’s requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her tricycle.

loans.use: Motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en:
Mrs. Yeng S., 32, has been a silk weaver for over ten years. Her husband, Mr. Kong Dam, has been a fisherman since 1985. The couple has been married since 1995 and lives on an island located fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Yeng has asked for a loan from Kiva one time before, and now she is requesting her second loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en: Ma. Luz V. has piggeryin Norala, South Cotabato.  She is 45 years old and has two children. Her oldest child is 14 years old.  She started her piggery in 2007.  She is asking for financial support to help finance her business.  She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP.  She will use the loan to buy more feed for her pigs.

loans.use: Pig feed

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma A. and her husband, Avelino, have three children ranging in age from 18 to 23 years old. Her eldest works abroad as a domestic helper and her second child is an unemployed high school graduate. In spite of the monthly remittance Vilma receives from her daughter abroad, she feels unhappy knowing that her child is working for other people the hard way. Instead of making herself feel guilty about her children's lives, she is inspired to work harder in her business to make it grow and become more stable. Once this happens, she will be asking her children to work with her and no longer enslave themselves abroad.

Vilma wants to grow her hog-raising business with the loan she's requested through ASHI. Her husband is a farm laborer and brings in income sporadically; therefore, she has to do her part to generate income for the family. She especially wants to support her youngest child in college (who will be graduating in the next two years).

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed required for fattening

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en: Nimfa R., 56 years old, manages a sari-sari store in Norala, South Cotabato. She started her store with a small amount of capital in 2000. With great effort to make her business productive, she now has a piggery and poultry business. Nimfa is the mother of six children. With her business, she has been able to send her children to school. Now she’s requesting a loan of 21,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to expand her piggery and poultry business.

loans.use: To buy groceries, pigs and chickens

loans.name: Trần Thị's Group

texts.en:
N. Trần Thị (10117110018) is a 39-year-old female living in the town of Đông Anh - Hà nội.  N. is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Xóm Thượng 11 (3).


N. is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, N. operates a butcher shop, butchering & selling pork in the local community.  N. has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 2.000.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2003, N. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  N. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6.750.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5.886.000 VND, which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  The loan will be the eighth loan taken out by N. from SEDA.  N. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Vương Thị T. (10117110039) is a 45-year-old female who is requesting a 5.450.000 VND loan to support her business operating a butcher shop.


2.  Hoàng Thị T. (10117110023) is a 35-year-old female who is requesting a 7.194.000 VND loan to support her business operating a service-based business.


3.  Hoàng Đình M. (10117110021) is a 49-year-old male who is requesting a 7.194.000 VND loan to support his business raising livestock.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (10117110022) is a 27-year-old female who is requesting a 7.194.000 VND loan to support her business operating a butcher shop.


5.  Hoàng Thị L. (10117110020) is a 51-year-old female who is requesting a 7.194.000 VND loan to support her business operating a specialized retail store.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


N. Trần Thị (10117110018) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà nội.  N. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Xóm Thượng 11 (3).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ giết mổ & bán thịt heo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  N. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, N. kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND.  Vào 2003, N. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  N. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 6.750.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.886.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 8th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Vương Thị T. (10117110039) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.450.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng thịt.


2.  Hoàng Thị T. (10117110023) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.194.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


3.  Hoàng Đình M. (10117110021) là 49 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.194.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (10117110022) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.194.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng thịt.


5.  Hoàng Thị L. (10117110020) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.194.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Annie

texts.en: Annie R. is an entrepreneur from Norala, South Cotabato. She started with a small sari-sari store in 2004. Now she manages a piggery. She is 57 years old supporting six children in her family. She needs additional capital to expand her business. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because it has low interest charges in financing. She’s requesting a loan of 21,000 Philippine pesos to buy groceries for her store and repair her piggery house.

loans.use: To buy groceries and repair a piggery

loans.name: Fritzie

texts.en:
Fritzie E. has had a piggery business since 2007.  She is 31 years old, with 2 children, and lives in Norala, South Cotabato.  Her eldest child is still 4 years old.  She also does meat vending to earn additional income for her family.  

She requested a loan of Php 21,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to finance her business with a low interest charge.  This loan will be very helpful to improve her business and to have more resources to utilize.

loans.use: Feed for pigs

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: As a mother, Jacqueline P. wanted to save her children from experiencing life being poor. She knew very well how hard and cruel it could be to a person without her own stable source of income. Because of this, she joined ASHI just recently to access a loan, which will finance her in starting a business. The primary business for which she will be using the loan is a hog fattening business. Once hogs are fattened after three to four months, they will be sold either whole or slaughtered, and pork will be sold per kilo. With her proceeds, she hopes that the basic needs of her seven children will be met. Having failed with her three eldest children who have not even graduated from high school, Jacqueline also wants to support the needs of her four younger children in school until they graduate from college.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase piglets and required food

loans.name: Malis

texts.en:
Malis N., 24, is single and has been a silk weaver since she was 12 years old. She lives with her brothers and sisters and widower father on an island on Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her father is a rice farmer and raises pigs at home. 

Malis is asking for a loan of $100 to repair a water pumping machine for her father in his farming business.

loans.use: To repair water pumping machine

loans.name: But

texts.en: Normally, Mrs. But S. and her husband get up in early morning, when the sky is still dark, to go buy fish in bulk from fishermen and then they hurry to bring their fish to sell at the market for a profit. In addition, But S.’s husband uses his motorcycle to pick up passengers for fees. This couple hastwo children, who are employed in garment industry. In order to earn extra income, But S. is applying for a loan to be used to purchase feed and piglets to begin raising.

loans.use: To purchase feed and piglets

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita L., 54, is a traveling fish vendor.  She also owns a sari-sari (retail store) as a source of income. Her family lives in Norala, South Cotabato.  She is married to Jose and has four children. Together, they support each other to sustain the daily needs of the family.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to obtain a loan that has a low interest rate. She has requested the amount of 18,000 PHP, enough to buy groceries for her store and support in financing her fish vending business.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for resale at her store, and to finance her fish vending business

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua is 30 years old and married with a three-year-old daughter. He sells kitchenware, such as thermo flasks, cups, house slippers, and plates. He says he has a good business environment in Machakos because it is in the interior and has few local competitors. He has run his business for three years and makes some extra income growing and selling vegetables. 

He is requesting a loan for Kes. 20,000 to purchase more stock of kitchenware. He hopes to increase his sales and own permanent premises instead of the mobile business he has been operating. He describes himself as very hardworking and a visionary, and he would like to expand his business to create employment for other people in his village.

loans.use: Add stock of kitchenware

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario R. needs additional capital for her sari-sari (retail store) business.  She also sells vegetables to her neighborhood in Norala, South Cotabato. She is 52 years old and married to Rolando R.. She does wholesale and retail in selling vegetables.

She would like to request a loan of 8,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to finance her growing business.

loans.use: Groceries and vegetables

loans.name: Antonietta

texts.en:
Antonietta L. is a vendor in Norala, South Cotabato.  She is 54 years old, married, and has six children.  She started her business in 2000, with a limited amount of capital totaling 3,000. Now she is grateful that her efforts have not been in vain.  Her business grew and she was able to send her children to school and provide the needs of her family.  

Now she’s requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., of 21,000 PHP.  This loan will help her expand her business with a low interest.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda Mayug, 51, earns a living through her sari-sari (retail) store. She also has a business in dress making in her neighborhood in Norala, South Cotabato.  She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to obtain a loan necessary for her business with a low interest rate. She has requested an amount of 12,000 PHP as additional capital for her sari-sari store.

loans.use: Groceries

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Mr. Ret R., 26 (was not in the photo, but his wife is available instead) and his wife, Mrs. Thary Hong, 30, married in 2004 and have a young son. The couple is living along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Ret has been selling jars for three years. He buys them from his village and transports them to sell at the other districts far from his house. His wife has been raising pigs at home for one year. Ret is requesting his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a remoque in which to carry jars to sell. A remoque is a motorbike attached with a trailer at the back.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer for carrying jars to sell

loans.name: Lhane

texts.en: Lhane D. R. manages a welding shop in Norala, South Cotabato.  She started her shop in 1984.  Her business supports her family.  She has nine children; her eldest child is 27 years old.  She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to help finance her business with a low interest rate.  She’s requesting a loan of 18,000 PHP to buy materials for her shop.

loans.use: To buy materials for her shop

loans.name: Khoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Khoeurn M. is from Tuol Kandal Village, Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Phom Nan, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. Unfortunately, however, their field is infertile. Consequently, Mrs. Khoeurn M. is requesting a loan so that she can buy fertilizer to support the field and thus make her crop more productive. She is the mother of two children, both of whom are attending the local school.

loans.use: purchasing fertilizer

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina P. owns a sari-sari (retail) store in Norala, South Cotabato.  She is 58 years old and married to William P..  They have five children to support. Their eldest child is 32 years old. They wish to expand their business but have limited capital.  

She heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc., which offers financial assistance with low interest. She joined in November of 2007.  Now she would like to request a loan of 16,000 PHP to continually support her business and help sustain her family.

loans.use: Groceries

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Angela Barabona is a 40-year old entrepreneur living in Norala, South Cotabato. She started with little capital in the amount of 2,500 PHP for her sari-sari (retail) store in 2007. After all her efforts to make her business bigger, she was able to provide for the financial needs of her five children, sending them to school.  

She needs additional capital in the amount of 18,000 PHP as a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to buy groceries for her store and make it more productive.

loans.use: Groceries

loans.name: Phum

texts.en: Phum M. is 44 years old and generates a daily income of $5 per day by selling fish. She is married to Yan, who is 32 years old and owns a trailer-motorbike taxi service. He also earns approximately $5 each day to help manage the family's expenses. They have four children who go to the local public school. This fish season, Phum M. and her husband hope to earn more money by investing as fish catchers but they don't have enough capital. Because of this, Phum M. would like to seek a loan to buy nets, traps, and a fishing boat for fishing activities. Phum M.'s husband appears in the photo.

loans.use: To buy nets, traps, and a boat

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 43 years old and married with three children between the ages of 6 and 15 years old. He runs a green grocery in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. He sells paw paws, bananas, and tomatoes. He also sells fruit at the Nursery Tree in Nairobi for extra income. He is requesting a loan for Kes. 30,000 to purchase mangoes and packing crates and to pay for transport between Machakos and Nairobi. He describes himself as a hardworking man and hopes to be able to expand sales into other nearby towns and supply his fruits to large hotels.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes and packing crates and to pay for transport

loans.name: Von

texts.en: Mr. Von D. is a villager in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Lay An, are farmers who own a 2 hectare field to cultivate rice. In his plantation, he faces a problem because his field is infertile having a bad effect on his crop. Thus, Mr. Von D. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the field and make it more productive. He is the father of a child who is working in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Tol

texts.en:
Mr. Tol S., 50, and his wife, Mrs. Saros Sen, 39, were married in 1983 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Tol's wife is in the picture. 

Tol and his wife have been fishing for over 30 years. They fish from Mekong River and lakes near the village and sell in the village market. Some of his fishing materials (fishing nets) are old, and they break down and don’t work well. So, he is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase new fishing nets to continue his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing nets

loans.name: Lê Thị's Group

texts.en: H. Lê Thị (10117070009) is a 45-year-old female living in the town of

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en: Corazon D. is a 63-year-old entrepreneur from Norala, South Cotabato.  Her main source of living is managing a sari-sari (retail) store.  She also sells dried fish and various foods.  She is the mother of six children.  She would like to request a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., in the amount of 8,000 PHP to buy supplies for her business.

loans.use: Groceries and dried fish

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch K. is a 27-year-old married mother who currently lives in the best territory of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She is a Khmer cake seller in the market, selling the cake that she makes in her home. She has two school-aged children. Another source of family income comes from her husband's working as a local chef. In addition, she will be using her loan to buy a small plot of farmland in a good location for farming. She will rent her land to the farmers for a fee.

loans.use: To buy a small plot of farmland in good location to rent to farmers

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly A., 35, is a married mother blessed with one teenage child who is studying at the local public school. She currently makes a living selling various cooking supplies from her home. She usually buys her produce items in bulk on credit, which she pays from her income after she finishes selling. She typically generates an income of $3.50 each day to help contribute to her family’s insufficient daily needs. Her husband assists with her in the business (he appears in the picture). Ly A. will be using her loan to accumulate the necessary quantity of cooking supplies to sell.

loans.use: To buy cooking supplies for resale

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda C. is from the village of Kiwalan, Iligan City. She is 58 years old. Minda is widowed and has an adult child. To make a living, Minda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Minda has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Minda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Minda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Minda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela B. is a 40-year old entrepreneur living in Norala, South Cotabato. She started with little capital in the amount of 2,500 PHP for her sari-sari (retail) store in 2007. After all her efforts to make her business bigger, she was able to provide for the financial needs of her five children, sending them to school.

She needs additional capital in the amount of 18,000 PHP as a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to buy groceries for her store and make it more productive.

loans.use: Groceries

loans.name: Mrs. Phea Roeun Tey Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phea Roeun T. is the mother of two young children and the president of her village bank. The bank has nine members, all of whom live in Prek Ruesse Village in Kandal Province. 

Mrs. Phea Roeun T. is a farmer who grows rice. Her husband, Mr. K. Chab, is fisherman. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she is requesting a loan to buy more fishing nets for her husband's fishing business. She will use the rest of the loan to fix her house. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more fishing nets and fix her house

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more slippers

loans.name: Mrs. Toeur Touch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group consists of ten people who live in Damrei Chhlang Village in Kandal Province. 

Mrs. Toeur T. was selected by the members to be the village bank president. She is a farmer who grows rice on a plot of land that she owns. She also sells fresh fish in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Vorn Vun, is a fisherman. Mr Vun does not have enough fishing nets, so Mrs. Toeur T. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishing nets to support her husband’s fishery. 

Mrs. Toeur T. is 35 years old and the mother of five children. Four of her children attend the local school; the youngest is too young to attend.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets for her husband’s fishing business

loans.name: Sokunthea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokunthea S. lives in Thlose Village in Takeo Province. She is 30 years old and the mother of two children. One of her children is enrolled in a local school; the other child is still too young. 

Mrs. Sokunthea Some grows rice on a plot of land that she owns and she breeds ducks. Since her poultry business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing 1000 more ducklings and duck food. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions. Her husband, Mr. Pak Kok, is a construction worker. (Mr. Pak Kok appears with Mrs. Sokunthea Some in the photo.)

loans.use: To buy 1000 more ducklings and duck food

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Srey Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Mom H. lives Tuol Kandal Village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer who grows rice on her 2-hectare (5-acre) farm. She does not have enough money to grow the rice, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides, and to hire laborer to work on her rice field. Her husband, Mr. Deip Sina, is a cow middleman. Mrs. Srey Mom H. is 29 years old and the mother of two children. One of her children attends the local school; the other child is too young for school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides, and to hire laborer to work on her rice field.

loans.name: Samoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Samoeun S. lives in Pour Ta Mouk Village in Takeo Province. She breeds ducks and sells duck eggs in the local market. Since her poultry business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing 750 more ducklings and duck food. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. 

Her husband, Mr. Heam Phorn, grows rice on a plot of land that he owns. He is also a fisherman. Mrs. Samoeun S. is 36 years old and the mother of three children. One of her children is a farmer, another child attends the local school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy 750 more ducklings and duck food

loans.name: Nhoeb
